statement.text: Cosmic inflation is a theory proposing that the universe underwent a period of exponential expansion in the first fraction of a second after the Big Bang (approximately 10^-36 to 10^-32 seconds). During inflation, the universe expanded by at least 60 e-foldings (a factor of ~10^26), solving several cosmological puzzles.
statement.formal: a(t) ‚àù exp(Ht) during inflation, where H is approximately constant

explanation.intuition: Imagine a tiny wrinkled balloon suddenly inflating to the size of a galaxy in an instant. Any wrinkles (inhomogeneities) would be stretched smooth, and regions that were once in contact would now be far apart. This explains why distant parts of the universe look so similar.
explanation.key_insight: Inflation connects Planck-scale quantum fluctuations to the largest cosmic structures. Quantum fluctuations during inflation, stretched to cosmic scales, became the seeds for galaxies and the patterns in the cosmic microwave background.

problems_solved.description: Why is the CMB temperature the same everywhere when distant regions were never in causal contact?
problems_solved.solution: Before inflation, these regions were in contact; inflation stretched them apart

problems_solved.description: Why is the universe so close to spatially flat?
problems_solved.solution: Inflation drives curvature toward zero regardless of initial conditions

problems_solved.description: Why don't we see magnetic monopoles predicted by GUTs?
problems_solved.solution: Inflation dilutes any pre-existing monopoles to negligible density
